hero.title: How to help a child learn on their own?
hero.description: Mamamonte proposes an environment where children can find the joy of learning themselves and grow independently. Autonomous learning is not just studying alone, but a process of choosing and concentrating according to inner motivation.

card1.title: 1. Prepared Environment
card1.description: A space organized with educational materials and tools suitable for the child's developmental stage is needed. Low shelves and intuitive layouts that allow children to take out and put back items independently instill independence and a sense of competence. This goes beyond mere tidiness, providing the foundation for children to choose and lead their own activities.

card2.title: 2. Free Choice and Respect
card2.description: Let the child choose what to do today. When children are immersed in activities of their own choosing, their concentration and responsibility are maximized. By respecting the child's choices, we help them practice taking responsibility for their decisions. Freedom of choice is the most important element that allows children to follow their inner needs and developmental requirements.

card3.title: 3. Parents as Observers
card3.description: Rather than trying to teach, watch quietly how the child interacts. The secret to not hindering a child's sense of achievement is to intervene only when help is truly needed. Through observation, we can accurately understand what developmental stage the child is currently in and what they are interested in.

card4.title: 4. Value of Mistakes and Repetition
card4.description: It's okay to be wrong. In the process of correcting errors and repeating by themselves, children realize deeper principles and gain confidence. Mamamonte values the process more than the result, giving children time to repeat and explore sufficiently. Through repetitive activities, children develop muscle control and reach a state of mental concentration.

hero.title: How to Cultivate the Power to Learn on Your Own
hero.description: Self-directed learning is not an innate ability, but a habit that can be cultivated through practice. Introducing the 3 most effective key steps.

step1.title: Step 1: Specific Goal Setting
step1.description: Instead of vaguely saying 'study well', set measurable goals like 'read 10 pages every day'. Specific goals clarify what the child needs to do, increasing execution.

step2.title: Step 2: Strategic Planning & Action
step2.description: Use a study planner to let the child allocate study amount and time themselves. It becomes truly theirs only when it includes an 'output' process of explaining what was learned or writing it on a blank paper, not just passive 'input'.

step3.title: Step 3: Objective Evaluation & Improvement
step3.description: Time is needed to reflect on whether today's learning went according to plan. Through metacognition that identifies 'what I know and what I don't know', you can supplement deficiencies and revise the next plan more realistically.

hero.title: Montessori Guide for Happy Parenting
hero.description: Respect your child as an individual and trust their power to grow on their own. Introducing parenting tips that make both parents and children happy.

environment.title: 1. Creating a 'Prepared Environment' for Independence
environment.description: Set up an environment at the child's eye level, such as low cabinets where they can take out clothes themselves, and small cups for drinking water. A safe space where they can explore freely instead of hearing 'No' fosters autonomy. When children feel they can control the space they stay in, their self-esteem and autonomy grow rapidly.

respect.title: 2. Respect & Observation: Wait until they ask for help
respect.description: Even if the child seems clumsy, watch rather than helping immediately. The sense of achievement when they do it themselves is the source of self-esteem. Intervening minimally only when help is needed is true respect. 'I did it myself!' is the most powerful weapon a child needs to live in the world.

tantrums.title: 3. Understanding the Tantrums
tantrums.description: Tantrums are a clumsy way for children to express their emotions or needs. Instead of scolding or giving in, first validate their feelings by saying 'You must be very upset'. Then clearly and consistently communicate what is allowed and what is not. While accepting emotions, firm discipline is needed for inappropriate behavior.

q1.question: At what age is it best to start Montessori education?
q1.answer: Montessori education can start from the moment of birth. 0-3 years is the period when the 'absorbent mind' is strongest, taking in the surrounding environment as it is. Just creating an environment at home that fits the child's developmental stage is a great start.

q2.question: My house is small, how can I create a 'prepared environment'?
q2.answer: You don't need grand educational materials. Start by placing things the child uses in low places within their reach. Just by designating a place for things using small baskets, the child learns a sense of order and develops the power to do things themselves.

q3.question: Is it okay if my child keeps repeating the same thing?
q3.answer: It's a very good sign! In Montessori education, 'repetition' is a key process for developing concentration and muscle control. Please watch without interrupting so the child can continue the activity until they are sufficiently satisfied. Through repetition, the child gains inner peace.
